subject: Re: [junit] Timeout tests and thread-local dependencies
msgSnippet: I don t know Hibernate/Spring well, so this is a shot in the dark... ... Can that default be overridden? David
messageBody:
I don't know Hibernate/Spring well, so this is a shot in the dark...

On Thu, Dec 31, 2009 at 12:54 PM, Berin <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> I'm trying to test some behavior using Hibernate/Spring transactional support, but I'm running into a particular snag.  By default, the transaction manager is bound to the current thread.

Can that default be overridden?

David

>
> Problem is that with tests that have the "timeout" attribute specified, JUnit creates a new thread to ensure the timeout is enforced.  For example:
>
> @Test(timeout=100)
> public void makeSureActionHappenedRecently() {
>    AuditLog.get().logEvent(EventType.TestEvent, "Foo");
>
>    Collection<AuditEvent> log =
>        AuditLog.get().findEventsFor(EventType.TestEvent);
>
>   assertNotEmpty(log);
>   // make sure timestamp is within X ms
>   assertRecent(100, log.iterator().next().getTimestamp());
> }
>
> This works without the (timeout=100) qualification because Hibernate is set up in the @BeforeClass.
>
> Technically I could put the set up in an @Before method, but that becomes rather expensive (setting up Spring, Hibernate, connecting to database).
>
> Any clues on how to make this work?
>
